newsitem.title: CANADA: CanAmera Foods switchs Hamilton to soybean crush.
newsitem.headline: CanAmera Foods switchs Hamilton to soybean crush.

text.p: CanAmera Foods last week switched its largest crushing plant in Hamilton, Ontario, from a dual canola and soybean processing facility to exclusively crush soybeans, Saskatchewan Wheat Pool chief executive Don Loewen told Reuters.

"This is not permanent. There's a soybean plant and a canola plant. We changed the canola plant into what we call a swing plant and we're able to swing it either onto canola or soybeans depending on the crush margins and we just started that (crushing soybeans) last week," Loewen said.
Low profit margins on canola crush forced plant slowdowns.
Three of Canada's five canola crushers, including CanAmera, announced reduced production runs in October.
CanAmera's canola plant in Hamilton crushed between 600 to 700 tonnes of canola each day, Loewen said.
"When we switched over to beans, the 700-tonne canola plant became about a 1,500-tonne soybean plant so it's a significant switch," Loewen said.
"The other soybean plant is larger," he added.
CanAmera is 50 percent owned by Saskatchewan Wheat Pool, Manitoba Pool Elevators and 50 percent by Central Soya, a unit of private French company Eridania Begain-Say.
